<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gesupietrochiave.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gesupietrochiave.jpg/220px-Gesupietrochiave.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gesupietrochiave.jpg/330px-Gesupietrochiave.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gesupietrochiave.jpg/440px-Gesupietrochiave.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1152" data-file-height="1103" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gesupietrochiave.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>According to Catholic doctrine, popes are successors of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <b>history of the papacy</b>, the office held by the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a> as head of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>, according to Catholic doctrine, spans from the time of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a> to the present day.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Early_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Church">Early Church</a>, the bishops of Rome enjoyed no <a href="/wiki/Temporal_power_(papal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Temporal power (papal)">temporal power</a> <a href="/wiki/Bishops_of_Rome_under_Constantine_I" title="Bishops of Rome under Constantine I">until the time of Constantine</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of Rome</a> (the "<a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>", about 476), the papacy was influenced by the temporal rulers of the surrounding <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a>; these periods are known as the <a href="/wiki/Ostrogothic_Papacy" title="Ostrogothic Papacy">Ostrogothic Papacy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Papacy" title="Byzantine Papacy">Byzantine Papacy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Papacy" title="Frankish Papacy">Frankish Papacy</a>. Over time, the papacy consolidated its territorial claims to a portion of the peninsula known as the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>. Thereafter, the role of neighboring sovereigns was replaced by powerful Roman families during the <i><a href="/wiki/Saeculum_obscurum" title="Saeculum obscurum">saeculum obscurum</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Crescentii" title="Crescentii">Crescentii</a> era, and the <a href="/wiki/Tusculan_Papacy" title="Tusculan Papacy">Tusculan Papacy</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_papacy_(1048%E2%80%931257)" title="History of the papacy (1048–1257)">From 1048 to 1257</a>, the papacy experienced increasing conflict with the leaders and churches of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> (Eastern Roman Empire).  The latter culminated in the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a>, dividing the Western Church and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Church">Eastern Church</a>.  From 1257–1377, the pope, though the bishop of Rome, resided in <a href="/wiki/Viterbo_Papacy" title="Viterbo Papacy">Viterbo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orvieto_Papacy" title="Orvieto Papacy">Orvieto</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Perugia_Papacy" title="Perugia Papacy">Perugia</a>, and then <a href="/wiki/Avignon_Papacy" title="Avignon Papacy">Avignon</a>. The return of the popes to Rome after the Avignon Papacy was followed by the <a href="/wiki/Western_Schism" title="Western Schism">Western Schism</a>:  the division of the western church between two and, for a time, three competing papal claimants.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Papacy" title="Renaissance Papacy">Renaissance Papacy</a> is known for its artistic and architectural patronage, forays into European power politics, and theological challenges to papal authority.  After the start of the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Reformation_Papacy" title="Reformation Papacy">Reformation Papacy</a> and Baroque Papacy led the Catholic Church through the <a href="/wiki/Counter-Reformation" title="Counter-Reformation">Counter-Reformation</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Popes_during_the_Age_of_Revolution" title="Popes during the Age of Revolution">popes during the Age of Revolution</a> witnessed the largest expropriation of wealth in the church's history, during the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> and those that followed throughout Europe. The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Question" title="Roman Question">Roman Question</a>, arising from <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italian unification</a>, resulted in the loss of the Papal States and the creation of <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>.
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Middle_Ages_(493–1417)"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Middle Ages (493–1417)</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Ostrogothic_Papacy_(493–537)"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Ostrogothic Papacy (493–537)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Byzantine_Papacy_(537–752)"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Byzantine Papacy (537–752)</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#Influence_of_powerful_Roman_families_(904–1048)"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Influence of powerful Roman families (904–1048)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9"><a href="#Conflicts_with_the_Emperor_and_East_(1048–1257)"><span class="tocnumber">2.5</span> <span class="toctext">Conflicts with the Emperor and East (1048–1257)</span></a></li>

</li>

<h2><span id="During_the_Roman_Empire_.28until_493.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="During_the_Roman_Empire_(until_493)">During the Roman Empire (until 493)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: During the Roman Empire (until 493)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christianity">Early Christianity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Early Christianity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Primacy_of_Simon_Peter" class="mw-redirect" title="Primacy of Simon Peter">Primacy of Simon Peter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians_in_the_Roman_Empire" title="Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire">Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire</a></div>
<p>Catholics and the Orthodox recognize the pope as the successor to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CCC881_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCC881-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kirsch_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kirsch-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and recognize him as the first bishop of Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-CEPope_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CEPope-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Official declarations of the Church speak of the popes as holding within the college of the bishops a position analogous to that held by Peter within the "college" of the <a href="/wiki/Apostle_(Christian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostle (Christian)">Apostles</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/Prince_of_the_Apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince of the Apostles">Prince of the Apostles</a>, of which the college of the Bishops, a distinct entity, is viewed by some to be the successor.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many deny that Peter and those claimed to be his immediate successors had universally-recognized supreme authority over all the early churches, citing instead that the Bishop of Rome was, and is, "first among equals" as stated by the Patriarch of the Orthodox Church in the 2nd century A.D. and again in the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> However, what that form should take is a matter of debate and contention, to this very day, between the Catholic and Orthodox Churches, which were one Church for at least the first seven ecumenical councils and until the formal split over Papal primacy in 1054 AD. 
</p><p>Many of the bishops of Rome in the first three centuries of the Christian era are obscure figures. Most of Peter's successors in the first three centuries following his life suffered martyrdom along with members of their flock in periods of persecution.
</p>
<h3><span id="From_Constantine_.28312.E2.80.93493.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="From_Constantine_(312–493)">From Constantine (312–493)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: From Constantine (312–493)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bishops_of_Rome_under_Constantine_I" title="Bishops of Rome under Constantine I">Bishops of Rome under Constantine I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg/220px-Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg/330px-Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg/440px-Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1191" data-file-height="740" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Raphael_Baptism_Constantine.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Raphael's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Baptism_of_Constantine" title="The Baptism of Constantine">The Baptism of Constantine</a></i> depicts Sylvester I instead of his actual baptizer <a href="/wiki/Eusebius_of_Nicomedia" title="Eusebius of Nicomedia">Eusebius of Nicomedia</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Arian" class="mw-redirect" title="Arian">Arian</a> bishop.</div></div></div>
<p>The legend surrounding the victory of <a href="/wiki/Constantine_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine I">Constantine I</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Milvian_Bridge" title="Battle of the Milvian Bridge">Battle of the Milvian Bridge</a> (312) relates his vision of the <a href="/wiki/Chi_Rho" title="Chi Rho">Chi Rho</a> and the text <a href="/wiki/In_hoc_signo_vinces" title="In hoc signo vinces">in hoc signo vinces</a> in the sky, and reproducing this symbol on the shields of his troops. The following year, Constantine and <a href="/wiki/Licinius" title="Licinius">Licinius</a> proclaimed the toleration of Catholicism with the <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Milan" title="Edict of Milan">Edict of Milan</a>, and in 325, Constantine convened and presided over the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">First Council of Nicaea</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical council</a>. None of this, however, has particularly much to do with the pope, who did not even attend the Council; in fact, the first bishop of Rome to be contemporaneously referred to as <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> is <a href="/wiki/Pope_Damasus_I" title="Pope Damasus I">Damasus I</a> (366–84).<sup id="cite_ref-b6_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b6-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> Moreover, between 324 and 330, Constantine moved the capital of the Roman empire from Rome to Byzantium, a former Greek city on the Bosporus. The power of Rome was transferred to Byzantium which later, in 330 became <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>  and today is Istanbul.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The "<a href="/wiki/Donation_of_Constantine" title="Donation of Constantine">Donation of Constantine</a>", an 8th-century forgery used to enhance the prestige and authority of popes, places the pope more centrally in the <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great_and_Christianity" title="Constantine the Great and Christianity">narrative of Constantinian Christianity</a>. The legend of the Donation claims that Constantine offered his crown to <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sylvester_I" title="Pope Sylvester I">Sylvester I</a> (314–35), and even that Sylvester baptized Constantine.  In reality, Constantine was baptized (nearing his death in May 337) by <a href="/wiki/Eusebius_of_Nicomedia" title="Eusebius of Nicomedia">Eusebius of Nicomedia</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Arian" class="mw-redirect" title="Arian">Arian</a> bishop.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the "Donation" never occurred, Constantine did hand over the <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Palace" title="Lateran Palace">Lateran Palace</a> to the bishop of Rome, and around 310 AD began the construction of <b>Basilica of Constantine</b> in Germany, called <a href="/wiki/Aula_Palatina" title="Aula Palatina">Aula Palatina</a>.
</p><p>Emperor Constantine also erected the Old St. Peter's Basilica, or Constantinian Basilica, the current location of the current, Renaissance era, St.Peter's Basilica within the Vatican, on the place of St. Peter's burial, as held by the Catholic community of Rome, after his conversion to Catholicism.
</p>
<h2><span id="Middle_Ages_.28493.E2.80.931417.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages_(493–1417)">Middle Ages (493–1417)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Middle Ages (493–1417)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span id="Ostrogothic_Papacy_.28493.E2.80.93537.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ostrogothic_Papacy_(493–537)">Ostrogothic Papacy (493–537)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Ostrogothic Papacy (493–537)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ostrogothic_Papacy" title="Ostrogothic Papacy">Ostrogothic Papacy</a></div>
<p>The <b>Ostrogothic Papacy</b> period ran from 493 to 537.  The papal election of March 483 was the first to take place without the existence of a Western Roman emperor. The papacy was strongly influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Ostrogothic_Kingdom" title="Ostrogothic Kingdom">Ostrogothic Kingdom</a>, if the pope was not <a href="/wiki/Papal_appointment" title="Papal appointment">outright appointed</a> by the Ostrogothic King. The selection and administration of popes during this period was strongly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Theodoric_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Theodoric the Great">Theodoric the Great</a> and his successors <a href="/wiki/Athalaric" title="Athalaric">Athalaric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theodahad" title="Theodahad">Theodahad</a>. This period terminated with <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a>'s (re)conquest of Rome during the <a href="/wiki/Gothic_War_(535%E2%80%93554)" title="Gothic War (535–554)">Gothic War</a>, inaugurating the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Papacy" title="Byzantine Papacy">Byzantine Papacy</a> (537–752).
</p><p>The role of the Ostrogoths became clear in the first schism, when, on November 22, 498, two men were elected pope. The subsequent triumph of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Symmachus" title="Pope Symmachus">Pope Symmachus</a> (498–514) over <a href="/wiki/Antipope_Laurentius" title="Antipope Laurentius">Antipope Laurentius</a> is the first recorded example of <a href="/wiki/Simony" title="Simony">simony</a> in papal history.<sup id="cite_ref-r70_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-r70-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Symmachus also instituted the practice of popes naming their own successors, which held until an unpopular choice was made in 530, and discord continued until the selection in 532 of <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_II" title="Pope John II">John II</a>, the first to rename himself upon succession.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Theoderic_the_Great" title="Theoderic the Great">Theodoric</a> was tolerant towards the Catholic Church and did not interfere in dogmatic matters. He remained as neutral as possible towards the pope, though he exercised a preponderant influence in the affairs of the papacy.<sup id="cite_ref-ce_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ce-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Ostrogothic influence ended with the reconquest of Rome by Justinian, who had had pro-Gothic <a href="/wiki/Pope_Silverius" title="Pope Silverius">Pope Silverius</a> (536–537) deposed and replaced with his own choice, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Vigilius" title="Pope Vigilius">Pope Vigilius</a> (537–555).
</p>
<h3><span id="Byzantine_Papacy_.28537.E2.80.93752.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Byzantine_Papacy_(537–752)">Byzantine Papacy (537–752)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Byzantine Papacy (537–752)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg/220px-Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="298" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg/330px-Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg/440px-Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1409" data-file-height="1907" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Meister_von_San_Vitale_in_Ravenna.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> re-conquered Rome and appointed the next three popes.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Papacy" title="Byzantine Papacy">Byzantine Papacy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Papacy" title="Byzantine Papacy">Byzantine Papacy</a> was a period of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> domination of the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">papacy</a> from 537 to 752, when popes required the approval of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Byzantine_emperors" title="List of Byzantine emperors">Byzantine Emperors</a> for <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Consecration">episcopal consecration</a>, and many popes were chosen from the <i><a href="/wiki/Apocrisiarius" title="Apocrisiarius">apocrisiarii</a></i> (liaisons from the pope to the emperor) or the inhabitants of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greece" title="Byzantine Greece">Byzantine Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria_(Roman_province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Syria (Roman province)">Syria</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Sicilia_(Roman_province)" title="Sicilia (Roman province)">Sicily</a>. <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> conquered the Italian peninsula in the <a href="/wiki/Gothic_War_(535%E2%80%93554)" title="Gothic War (535–554)">Gothic War (535–54)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papal_selection_before_1059" title="Papal selection before 1059">appointed the next three popes</a>, a practice that would be continued by his successors and later be delegated to the <a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna" title="Exarchate of Ravenna">Exarchate of Ravenna</a>.
</p><p>With the exception of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Martin_I" title="Pope Martin I">Pope Martin I</a>, no pope during this period questioned the authority of the Byzantine monarch to confirm the election of the <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop of Rome">bishop of Rome</a> before consecration could occur; however, theological conflicts were common between pope and emperor in the areas such as <a href="/wiki/Monotheletism" class="mw-redirect" title="Monotheletism">monotheletism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iconoclasm" title="Iconoclasm">iconoclasm</a>. Greek speakers from Greece, Syria, and Byzantine Sicily replaced members of the powerful Roman nobles in the papal chair during this period. Rome under the Greek popes constituted a "melting pot" of Western and Eastern Christian traditions, reflected in art as well as liturgy.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_I" title="Pope Gregory I">Pope Gregory I</a> (590–604) was a major figure in asserting <a href="/wiki/Papal_primacy" title="Papal primacy">papal primacy</a> and gave the impetus to missionary activity in northern Europe, including England.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Rome" title="Duchy of Rome">Duchy of Rome</a> was a Byzantine district in the Exarchate of Ravenna, ruled by an imperial functionary with the title dux. Within the exarchate, the two chief districts were the country about Ravenna where the exarch was the centre of Byzantine opposition to the Lombards, and the Duchy of Rome, which embraced the lands of Latium north of the Tiber and of Campania to the south as far as the Garigliano. There the pope himself was the soul of the opposition.
</p><p>The pains were taken, as long as possible, to retain control of the intervening districts and with them communication over the Apennine mountains. In 728, the Lombard King Liutprand took the Castle of <a href="/wiki/Sutri" title="Sutri">Sutri</a>, on the road to Perugia, but restored it to Pope Gregory II "as a gift to the blessed Apostles Peter and Paul". The popes continued to acknowledge the imperial Government.
</p><p>In 738, the Lombard duke Transamund of Spoleto captured the Castle of Gallese, which protected the road to Perugia. By a large payment, Pope Gregory III induced the duke to restore the castle to him.
</p>
<h3><span id="Frankish_influence_.28756.E2.80.93857.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Frankish_influence_(756–857)">Frankish influence (756–857)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Frankish influence (756–857)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Papacy" title="Frankish Papacy">Frankish Papacy</a></div>
<p>In 751, <a href="/wiki/Aistulf" title="Aistulf">Aistulf</a> took Ravenna and threatened Rome. In response to this threat, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Stephen_II" title="Pope Stephen II">Pope Stephen II</a> made an unusual journey north of the Alps to visit the Frankish king, <a href="/wiki/Pepin_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Pepin III">Pepin III</a>, to seek his help against the invading Lombards. The papal elections were marked by battles between various secular and ecclesiastical factions frequently entangled in the power politics of Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-g13_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g13-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The pope anointed Pepin at the abbey of St Denis, near Paris, together with Pepin's two young sons <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charles</a> and Carloman. Pepin duly invaded northern Italy in 754, and again in 756. Pepin was able to drive the Lombards from the territory belonging to Ravenna but he did not restore it to its rightful owner, the Byzantine emperor. Instead, he handed over large areas of central Italy to the pope and his successors.
</p><p>The land given to pope Stephen in 756, in the so-called <a href="/wiki/Donation_of_Pepin" title="Donation of Pepin">Donation of Pepin</a>, made the papacy a temporal power and for the first time created an incentive for secular leaders to interfere with <a href="/wiki/Papal_selection_before_1059" title="Papal selection before 1059">papal succession</a>. This territory would become the basis for the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>, over which the popes ruled until the Papal States were incorporated into the new <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> in 1870. For the next eleven centuries, the story of Rome would be almost synonymous with the story of the papacy.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lombards" title="Lombards">Lombard kingdom</a> reached its height in the 7th and 8th century. Paganism and <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arianism</a> were at first prevalent among the Lombards but were gradually supplanted by Catholicism. Roman culture and Latin speech were gradually adopted and the Catholic bishops emerged as chief magistrates in the cities. Lombard law combined Germanic and Roman traditions. After Aistulf's death, King Desiderius renewed the attack on Rome. In 772, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Adrian_I" title="Pope Adrian I">Pope Adrian I</a> enlisted the support of <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>, Pepin's successor, who intervened, and, after defeating the Lombards, added their kingdom to his own.
</p><p>After being physically attacked by his enemies in the streets of Rome, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_III" title="Pope Leo III">Pope Leo III</a> made his way in 799 through the Alps to visit <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> at Paderborn.
</p><p>It is not known what was agreed between the two, but Charlemagne traveled to Rome in 800 to support the pope. In a ceremony in St Peter's Basilica, on Christmas Day, Leo was supposed to anoint Charlemagne's son as his heir. But unexpectedly (it is maintained), as Charlemagne rose from prayer, the pope placed a crown on his head and acclaimed him emperor. It is reported that Charlemagne expressed displeasure but nevertheless accepted the honour. The displeasure was probably diplomatic, for the legal emperor was supposed to be seated in Constantinople. Nevertheless, this public alliance between the pope and the ruler of a confederation of Germanic tribes was a reflection of the reality of political power in the west. This coronation launched the concept of the new Holy Roman Empire which would play an important role throughout the Middle Ages. The <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> became formally established only in the next century. But the concept is implicit in the title adopted by Charlemagne in 800: 'Charles, most serene Augustus, crowned by God, great and pacific emperor, governing the Roman empire.'
</p><p>Charlemagne's successor, "Louis the Pious", intervened in the papal election by supporting the claim of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Eugene_II" title="Pope Eugene II">Pope Eugene II</a>; the popes henceforth were required to swear loyalty to the Frankish Emperor.<sup id="cite_ref-b14_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b14-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Papal subjects were made to swear loyalty to the Frankish Emperor and the consecration of the pope could be performed only in the presence of the Emperor's representatives.<sup id="cite_ref-eugene_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eugene-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> The consecration of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_IV" title="Pope Gregory IV">Pope Gregory IV</a> (827-844), chosen by the Roman nobles, was delayed for six months to attain the assent of Louis.<sup id="cite_ref-b14_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b14-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-greg_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greg-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sergius_II" title="Pope Sergius II">Pope Sergius II</a> (844-847), choice of the Roman nobility, was consecrated without reference to <a href="/wiki/Lothair_I" title="Lothair I">Emperor Lothaire</a>, the latter sent <a href="/wiki/Louis_II_of_Italy" title="Louis II of Italy">his son Louis</a> with an army, <sup id="cite_ref-serg_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-serg-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> and only when "Sergius succeeded in pacifying Louis, whom he crowned king" did <a href="/wiki/Lothair_I" title="Lothair I">Lothair I</a> side with Sergius II.<sup id="cite_ref-serg_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-serg-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Influence_of_powerful_Roman_families_.28904.E2.80.931048.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Influence_of_powerful_Roman_families_(904–1048)">Influence of powerful Roman families (904–1048)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Influence of powerful Roman families (904–1048)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saeculum_obscurum" title="Saeculum obscurum">Saeculum obscurum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crescentii" title="Crescentii">Crescentii</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tusculan_Papacy" title="Tusculan Papacy">Tusculan Papacy</a></div>
<p>The period beginning with the installation of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sergius_III" title="Pope Sergius III">Pope Sergius III</a> in 904 and lasting for sixty years until the death of <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XII" title="Pope John XII">Pope John XII</a> in 964 is sometimes referred to as <a href="/wiki/Saeculum_obscurum" title="Saeculum obscurum">Saeculum obscurum</a> or the "dark age." Historian <a href="/wiki/Will_Durant" title="Will Durant">Will Durant</a> refers to the period from 867 to 1049 as the "nadir of the papacy".<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During this period, the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">popes</a> were controlled by a powerful and corrupt aristocratic family, the <a href="/wiki/Theophylacti" class="mw-redirect" title="Theophylacti">Theophylacti</a>, and their relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Conflicts_with_the_Emperor_and_East_.281048.E2.80.931257.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Conflicts_with_the_Emperor_and_East_(1048–1257)">Conflicts with the Emperor and East (1048–1257)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Conflicts with the Emperor and East (1048–1257)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_papacy_(1048%E2%80%931257)" title="History of the papacy (1048–1257)">History of the papacy (1048–1257)</a></div>
<p>The Imperial crown once held by the Carolingian emperors was disputed between their fractured heirs and local overlords; none emerged victorious until <a href="/wiki/Otto_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor">Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor</a> invaded Italy. Italy became a <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(medieval)#Constituent_of_the_Holy_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Italy (medieval)">constituent kingdom</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> in 962, from which point the emperors were German. As emperors consolidated their position, northern Italian city-states would become divided by <a href="/wiki/Guelphs_and_Ghibellines" title="Guelphs and Ghibellines">Guelphs and Ghibellines</a>. <a href="/wiki/Henry_III,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor">Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor</a> found three rival popes when he visited Rome in 1048 because of the unprecedented actions of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_IX" title="Pope Benedict IX">Pope Benedict IX</a>. He deposed all three and installed his own preferred candidate: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_II" title="Pope Clement II">Pope Clement II</a>.
</p><p>The history of the papacy from 1048 to 1257 would continue to be marked by conflict between popes and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>, most prominently the <a href="/wiki/Investiture_Controversy" title="Investiture Controversy">Investiture Controversy</a>, a dispute over who—pope or emperor—could appoint bishops within the Empire. Henry IV's <a href="/wiki/Walk_to_Canossa" class="mw-redirect" title="Walk to Canossa">Walk to Canossa</a> in 1077 to meet <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_VII" title="Pope Gregory VII">Pope Gregory VII</a> (1073–85), although not dispositive within the context of the larger dispute, has become legendary. Although the emperor renounced any right to lay investiture in the <a href="/wiki/Concordat_of_Worms" title="Concordat of Worms">Concordat of Worms</a> (1122), the issue would flare up again.
</p><p>Long-standing divisions between East and West also came to a head in the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a>. The <a href="/wiki/First_seven_Ecumenical_Councils" class="mw-redirect" title="First seven Ecumenical Councils">first seven Ecumenical Councils</a> had been attended by both Western and Eastern prelates, but growing doctrinal, theological, linguistic, political and geographic differences finally resulted in mutual denunciations and excommunications. <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_II" title="Pope Urban II">Pope Urban II</a> (1088–99) speech at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Clermont" title="Council of Clermont">Council of Clermont</a> in 1095 became the rallying cry of the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a>.
</p><p>Unlike the <a href="/wiki/Papal_selection_before_1059" title="Papal selection before 1059">previous millennium</a>, the process for papal selection became somewhat fixed during this period. <a href="/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_II" title="Pope Nicholas II">Pope Nicholas II</a> promulgated <i><a href="/wiki/In_nomine_Domini" title="In nomine Domini">In nomine Domini</a></i> in 1059, which limited suffrage in papal elections to the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a>. The rules and procedures of papal elections evolved during this period, laying the groundwork for the modern <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">papal conclave</a>.  The driving force behind these reforms was Cardinal Hildebrand, who later became Gregory VII.
</p>
<h3><span id="The_wandering_popes_.281257.E2.80.931309.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_wandering_popes_(1257–1309)">The wandering popes (1257–1309)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: The wandering popes (1257–1309)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table align="right">

<tbody><tr>
<td style="vertical-align:top;"><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Viterbo,_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi,_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg/220px-Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg/330px-Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg/440px-Viterbo%2C_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi%2C_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2432" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Viterbo,_palazzo_e_loggia_dei_papi,_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_dei_Papi_di_Viterbo" title="Palazzo dei Papi di Viterbo">papal palace</a> in Viterbo...</div></div></div>
</td>
<td style="vertical-align:top;"><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG/220px-Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG/330px-Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG/440px-Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3888" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Palazzo_dei_Papi.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>...and Orvieto</div></div></div>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Viterbo_Papacy" title="Viterbo Papacy">Viterbo Papacy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orvieto_Papacy" title="Orvieto Papacy">Orvieto Papacy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Perugia_Papacy" title="Perugia Papacy">Perugia Papacy</a></div>
<p>The pope is the <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop of Rome">bishop of Rome</a>, but nowhere is it written that he has to stay there (in fact, only 200 years prior, cardinals would have been <a href="/wiki/External_cardinal" title="External cardinal">required to reside in Rome</a>). Political instability in thirteenth-century Italy forced the papal court to move to several different locations. Destinations included <a href="/wiki/Viterbo" title="Viterbo">Viterbo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orvieto" title="Orvieto">Orvieto</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Perugia" title="Perugia">Perugia</a>. The popes brought the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a> with them, and the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a> met in the city where the last pope had died to hold papal elections. Host cities enjoyed a boost to their prestige and certain economic advantages, but the municipal authorities risked being subsumed into the administration of the Papal States if they allowed the pope to overstay his welcome.
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Eamon_Duffy" title="Eamon Duffy">Eamon Duffy</a>, "aristocratic factions within the city of Rome once again made it an insecure base for a stable papal government. Innocent IV was exiled from Rome and even from Italy for six years, and all but two of the papal elections of the thirteenth century had to take place outside Rome. The skyline of Rome itself was now dominated by the fortified war-towers of the aristocracy (a hundred were built in Innocent IV's pontificate alone) and the popes increasingly spent their time in the papal palaces at Viterbo and Orvieto."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Avignon_Papacy_.281309.E2.80.931377.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Avignon_Papacy_(1309–1377)">Avignon Papacy (1309–1377)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Avignon Papacy (1309–1377)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Avignon,_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg/220px-Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="90" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg/330px-Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg/440px-Avignon%2C_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4241" data-file-height="1728" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Avignon,_Palais_des_Papes_by_JM_Rosier.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palais_des_Papes" title="Palais des Papes">Palais des Papes</a> in Avignon</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Avignon_Papacy" title="Avignon Papacy">Avignon Papacy</a></div>
<p>During this period, seven popes, all French, resided in Avignon starting in 1309: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_V" title="Pope Clement V">Pope Clement V</a> (1305–14), <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXII" title="Pope John XXII">Pope John XXII</a> (1316–34), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XII" title="Pope Benedict XII">Pope Benedict XII</a> (1334–42), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VI" title="Pope Clement VI">Pope Clement VI</a> (1342–52), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Innocent_VI" title="Pope Innocent VI">Pope Innocent VI</a> (1352–62), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_V" title="Pope Urban V">Pope Urban V</a> (1362–70), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_XI" title="Pope Gregory XI">Pope Gregory XI</a> (1370–78). The papacy was controlled by the French King in this time. In 1378, Gregory XI moved the papal residence back to Rome and died there.
</p>
<h3><span id="Western_Schism_.281378.E2.80.931417.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Schism_(1378–1417)">Western Schism (1378–1417)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Western Schism (1378–1417)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Western_schism_1378-1417.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Western_schism_1378-1417.svg/220px-Western_schism_1378-1417.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Western_schism_1378-1417.svg/330px-Western_schism_1378-1417.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Western_schism_1378-1417.svg/440px-Western_schism_1378-1417.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="770" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Western_schism_1378-1417.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The division of European allegiances at a point during the Western Schism.<br /><b>Caution</b>: this map is highly inaccurate in some regions and borders, see its <a href="/wiki/File_talk:Western_schism_1378-1417.svg" title="File talk:Western schism 1378-1417.svg">talk page</a>.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Western_Schism" title="Western Schism">Western Schism</a></div>
<p>After seventy years in France the papal curia was naturally French in its ways and, to a large extent, in its staff. Back in Rome some degree of tension between French and Italian factions was inevitable. This tension was brought to a head by the death of the French Pope <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_XI" title="Pope Gregory XI">Gregory XI</a> within a year of his return to Rome. The Roman crowd, said to be in threatening mood, demanded a Roman pope or at least an Italian one. In 1378, the conclave elected an Italian from Naples, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_VI" title="Pope Urban VI">Pope Urban VI</a>. His intransigence in office soon alienated the French cardinals. And the behaviour of the Roman crowd enabled them to declare, in retrospect, that his election was invalid, voted under duress.
</p><p>The French cardinals withdrew to a conclave of their own, where they elected one of their number, Robert of Geneva. He took the name <a href="/wiki/Antipope_Clement_VII" title="Antipope Clement VII">Clement VII</a>. By 1379, he was back in the palace of popes in Avignon, while Urban VI remained in Rome.
</p><p>This was the beginning of the period of difficulty from 1378 to 1417 which Catholic scholars refer to as the "Western Schism" or, "the great controversy of the antipopes" (also called "the second great schism" by some secular and Protestant historians), when parties within the Catholic Church were divided in their allegiances among the various claimants to the office of pope. The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Constance" title="Council of Constance">Council of Constance</a>, in 1417, finally resolved the controversy.
</p><p>For nearly forty years the Church had two papal curias and two sets of cardinals, each electing a new pope for Rome or Avignon when death created a vacancy. Each pope lobbied for support among kings and princes who played them off against each other, changing allegiance when according to political advantage.
</p><p>In 1409, a council was convened at Pisa to resolve the issue. The council declared both existing popes to be schismatic (Gregory XII from Rome, Benedict XIII from Avignon) and appointed a new one, Alexander V. But the existing popes had not been persuaded to resign, so the church had three popes.
</p><p>Another council was convened in 1414 at <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Constance" title="Council of Constance">Constance</a>. In March 1415, the Pisan pope, John XXIII, fled from Constance in disguise; he was brought back a prisoner and deposed in May. The Roman pope, Gregory XII, resigned voluntarily in July.
</p><p>The Avignon pope, Benedict XIII, refused to come to Constance. In spite of a personal visit from the <a href="/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor">emperor Sigismund</a>, he would not consider resignation. The council finally deposed him in July 1417. Denying their right to do so, he withdrew to an impregnable castle on the coast of Spain. Here he continued to act as pope, creating new cardinals and issuing decrees, until his death in 1423.
</p><p>The council in Constance, having finally cleared the field of popes and antipopes, elected <a href="/wiki/Pope_Martin_V" title="Pope Martin V">Pope Martin V</a> as pope in November.
</p>
<h2><span id="Early_Modern_and_Modern_Era_.281417.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Modern_and_Modern_Era_(1417–present)">Early Modern and Modern Era (1417–present)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Early Modern and Modern Era (1417–present)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span id="Renaissance_Papacy_.281417.E2.80.931534.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Renaissance_Papacy_(1417–1534)">Renaissance Papacy (1417–1534)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Renaissance Papacy (1417–1534)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Papacy" title="Renaissance Papacy">Renaissance Papacy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="291" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1928" data-file-height="2552" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Raffaello_Sanzio_-_Ritratto_di_Leone_X_coi_cardinali_Giulio_de%27_Medici_e_Luigi_de%27_Rossi_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_X" title="Pope Leo X">Pope Leo X</a> with his cousins <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VII" title="Pope Clement VII">Giulio de' Medici</a> <i>(left, the future Pope Clement VII)</i> and Luigi de' Rossi <i>(right)</i>, whom he appointed as <a href="/wiki/Cardinal-nephew" title="Cardinal-nephew">cardinal-nephews</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>From the election of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Martin_V" title="Pope Martin V">Pope Martin V</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Constance" title="Council of Constance">Council of Constance</a> in 1417 to the Reformation, Western Christianity was largely free from schism as well as significant <a href="/wiki/Antipope" title="Antipope">disputed papal claimants</a>. Martin V returned the papacy to Rome in 1420.  Although there were important divisions over the direction of the religion, these were resolved through the then-settled procedures of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">papal conclave</a>.
</p><p>Unlike their European peers, popes were not <a href="/wiki/Hereditary_monarchy" title="Hereditary monarchy">hereditary monarchs</a>, so they could only promote their family interests through <a href="/wiki/Nepotism" title="Nepotism">nepotism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-s369_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s369-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The word <i><a href="/wiki/Nepotism" title="Nepotism">nepotism</a></i> originally referred specifically to the practice of creating <a href="/wiki/Cardinal-nephew" title="Cardinal-nephew">cardinal-nephews</a>, when it appeared in the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a> about 1669.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> According to Duffy, "the inevitable outcome of all of this was a creation of a wealthy cardinalatial class, with strong dynastic connections."<sup id="cite_ref-d193_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d193-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> The College was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Cardinal-nephew" title="Cardinal-nephew">cardinal-nephews</a>—relatives of the popes that elevated them, <a href="/wiki/Crown-cardinal" title="Crown-cardinal">crown-cardinals</a>—representatives of the Catholic monarchies of Europe, and members of the powerful Italian families. The wealthy popes and cardinals increasingly patronized <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> art and architecture, (re)building the landmarks of <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> from the ground up.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a> began to resemble a modern <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> during this period, and the papacy took an increasingly active role in European wars and diplomacy. <a href="/wiki/Pope_Julius_II" title="Pope Julius II">Pope Julius II</a> become known as "the Warrior Pope" for his use of bloodshed to increase the territory and property of the papacy.<sup id="cite_ref-s368_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s368-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The popes of this period used the papal military not only to enrich themselves and their families, but also to enforce and expand upon the longstanding territorial and property claims of the papacy as an institution.<sup id="cite_ref-d190_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d190-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Although, before the Western Schism, the papacy had derived much of its revenue from the "vigorous exercise of its spiritual office," during this period the popes were financially dependent on the revenues from the Papal States themselves.  With ambitious expenditures on war and construction projects, popes turned to new sources of revenue from the sale of <a href="/wiki/Indulgence" title="Indulgence">indulgences</a> and bureaucratic and ecclesiastical offices.<sup id="cite_ref-d194_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d194-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VII" title="Pope Clement VII">Pope Clement VII</a>'s diplomatic and military campaigns resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Rome_(1527)" title="Sack of Rome (1527)">Sack of Rome</a> in 1527.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Popes were more frequently called upon to arbitrate disputes between competing colonial powers than to resolve complicated theological disputes. Columbus' discovery in 1492 upset the unstable relations between the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Castile" title="Crown of Castile">Castile</a>, whose jockeying for possession of colonial territories along the African coast had for many years been regulated by the papal bulls of 1455, 1456, and 1479. Alexander VI responded with three bulls, dated May 3 and 4, which were highly favorable to Castile; the third <i><a href="/wiki/Inter_caetera" title="Inter caetera">Inter caetera</a></i> (1493), awarded Spain the sole right to <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">colonize</a> most of the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>.
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Eamon_Duffy" title="Eamon Duffy">Eamon Duffy</a>, "the Renaissance papacy invokes images of a Hollywood spectacular, all decadence and drag. Contemporaries viewed Renaissance Rome as we now view Nixon's Washington, a city of expense-account whores and political graft, where everything and everyone had a price, where nothing and nobody could be trusted. The popes themselves seemed to set the tone."<sup id="cite_ref-d193_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d193-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> For example, Leo X was said to have remarked: "Let us enjoy the papacy, since God has given it to us."<sup id="cite_ref-s369_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s369-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Several of these popes <a href="/wiki/List_of_sexually_active_popes" title="List of sexually active popes">took mistresses and fathered children</a> and engaged in intrigue or even murder.<sup id="cite_ref-d193_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d193-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Alexander_VI" title="Pope Alexander VI">Alexander VI</a> had four acknowledged children: <a href="/wiki/Cesare_Borgia" title="Cesare Borgia">Cesare Borgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lucrezia_Borgia" title="Lucrezia Borgia">Lucrezia Borgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gioffre_Borgia" title="Gioffre Borgia">Gioffre Borgia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Borgia,_2nd_Duke_of_Gandia" title="Giovanni Borgia, 2nd Duke of Gandia">Giovanni Borgia</a> before he became Pope.
</p>
<h3><span id="Reformation_and_Counter-Reformation_.281517.E2.80.931580.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Reformation_and_Counter-Reformation_(1517–1580)">Reformation and Counter-Reformation (1517–1580)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Reformation and Counter-Reformation (1517–1580)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Reformation_Papacy" title="Reformation Papacy">Reformation Papacy</a></div>
<h3><span id="Baroque_Papacy_.281585.E2.80.931689.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Baroque_Papacy_(1585–1689)">Baroque Papacy (1585–1689)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Baroque Papacy (1585–1689)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The pontificate of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sixtus_V" title="Pope Sixtus V">Pope Sixtus V</a> (1585–1590) opened up the final stage of the Catholic Reformation, characteristic of the <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> age of the early seventeenth century, shifting away from compelling to attracting. His reign focused on rebuilding Rome as a great European capital and Baroque city, a visual symbol for the Catholic Church.
</p>
<h3><span id="During_the_Age_of_Revolution_.281775.E2.80.931848.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="During_the_Age_of_Revolution_(1775–1848)">During the Age of Revolution (1775–1848)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: During the Age of Revolution (1775–1848)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Popes_during_the_Age_of_Revolution" title="Popes during the Age of Revolution">Popes during the Age of Revolution</a></div>
<h3><span id="Roman_Question_.281870.E2.80.931929.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_Question_(1870–1929)">Roman Question (1870–1929)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Roman Question (1870–1929)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Roman_Question" title="Roman Question">Roman Question</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BrecciaPortaPia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/BrecciaPortaPia.jpg/220px-BrecciaPortaPia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/BrecciaPortaPia.jpg/330px-BrecciaPortaPia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/BrecciaPortaPia.jpg/440px-BrecciaPortaPia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6048" data-file-height="3728" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BrecciaPortaPia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The breach of the Porta Pia during the <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Rome" title="Capture of Rome">Capture of Rome</a></div></div></div>
<p>The provisional capital of Italy had been Florence since 1865. After defeating the papal forces in 1870, the Italian government moved to the banks of the Tiber a year later. Victor Emmanuel installed himself in the <a href="/wiki/Quirinal_Palace" title="Quirinal Palace">Quirinal Palace</a>. Rome became once again, for the first time in thirteen centuries, the capital city of a united Italy. Rome was unusual among capital cities only in that it contained the power of the pope and a small parcel of land (<a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>) beyond national control. This anomaly was not formally resolved until the <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaty" title="Lateran Treaty">Lateran pacts of 1929</a>.
</p><p>The last eight years of his long pontificate – the longest in Church history – <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a> spent as prisoner of the Vatican. Catholics were forbidden to vote or being voted in national elections.  However, they were permitted to participate in local elections, where they achieved successes.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Pius himself was active, during those years, by creating new diocesan seats and appointing bishops to numerous dioceses, which had been unoccupied for years.  Asked if he wanted his successor to follow his Italian policies, the old pontiff replied:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>My successor may be inspired by my love to the Church and my wish to do the right thing. Everything changed around me. My system and my policies had their time, I am too old to change direction. This will be the task of my successor.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_XIII" title="Pope Leo XIII">Pope Leo XIII</a>, considered a great diplomat, managed to improve relations with Russia, Prussia, German France, England and other countries. However, in light of a hostile anti-Catholic climate in Italy, he continued the policies of Pius IX towards Italy, without major modifications.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> He had to defend the freedom of the Church against Italian persecutions and attacks in the area of education, expropriation and violation of Catholic Churches, legal measures against the Church and brutal attacks, culminating in anticlerical groups attempting to throw the body of the deceased Pope Pius IX into the Tiber river on July 13, 1881.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> The pope even considered moving the papacy to <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> or <a href="/wiki/Salzburg" title="Salzburg">Salzburg</a>, two cities under <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austrian</a> control, an idea which the Austrian monarch <a href="/wiki/Franz_Josef_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Franz Josef I">Franz Josef I</a> gently rejected.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>His encyclicals changed Church positions on relations with temporal authorities, and, in the 1891 encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Rerum_novarum" title="Rerum novarum">Rerum novarum</a></i> addressed for the first time social inequality and social justice issues with Papal authority.  He was greatly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Emmanuel_von_Ketteler" title="Wilhelm Emmanuel von Ketteler">Wilhelm Emmanuel von Ketteler</a>, a German bishop who openly propagated siding with the suffering working classes<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> Since Leo XIII, Papal teachings expand on the right and obligation of workers and the limitations of private property: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Quadragesimo_anno" title="Quadragesimo anno">Quadragesimo anno</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Social_teachings_of_Pope_Pius_XII" title="Social teachings of Pope Pius XII">Social teachings of Pope Pius XII</a> on a huge range of social issues, <a href="/wiki/John_XXIII" class="mw-redirect" title="John XXIII">John XXIII</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Mater_et_magistra" title="Mater et magistra">Mater et magistra</a></i> in 1961, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a>, the encyclical <a href="/wiki/Populorum_progressio" title="Populorum progressio">Populorum progressio</a> on World development issues, and <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Centesimus_annus" title="Centesimus annus">Centesimus annus</a>, commemorating the 100th anniversary of </i>Rerum novarum<i> of Pope Leo XIII.</i>
</p><p>The eclipse of papal temporal power during the 19th century was accompanied by a recovery of papal prestige. The monarchist reaction in the wake of the French Revolution and the later emergence of constitutional governments served alike, though in different ways, to sponsor that development. The reinstated monarchs of Catholic Europe saw in the papacy a conservative ally rather than a jurisdictional rival. Later, when the institution of constitutional governments broke the ties binding the clergy to the policies of royal regimes, Catholics were freed to respond to the renewed spiritual authority of the pope.
</p><p>The popes of the 19th and 20th centuries exercised their spiritual authority with increasing vigor and in every aspect of religious life. By the crucial pontificate of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a> (1846–1878), for example, papal control over worldwide Catholic missionary activity was firmly established for the first time in history.
</p>
<h3><span id="From_the_creation_of_Vatican_City_.281929.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="From_the_creation_of_Vatican_City_(1929)">From the creation of Vatican City (1929)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_papacy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: From the creation of Vatican City (1929)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a></div>
